commentBody:
A fairly speedy Saturday but there was one thing this Canadian had to look up: Lenny & Larry‚Äôs? Never heard of them. 

Fun puzzle over all. Well done.
I had ENPLEINAIR crossed by DELTA, and had a really rough time sussing out the NW. Good puzzle Mr. Judge.

A nicely balanced puzzle with a tough grid.  It took me awhile to work out the NW corner.  I was also slowed a bit in the middle by trying torn acl before stumbling on TURFTOE. As a baseball fan I was helped by the appearance of the remarkable Shohei Ohtani.  Not since Babe Ruth has there been a player so gifted at both hitting and pitching.
Puzzles like this - heavy on trivia, light on wordplay - just aren't for me.
Man was breezing through this then got cooked by NW
I thought this was a fun puzzle, balanced with just enough challenge. I definitely had to suss out TURFTOE, ATAHUALPA and LARRYS, and i like the non-LOTR hint for ORC. Well done.

One of those puzzles where I was just in sync with the constructor. Record time for a Saturday, by a lot. I thought I might be hindered by some of the trivia, but everything came together with crosses. What a well made puzzle!
Adding my vote to the nastiness that was the NW corner. Sussed it out through

This one came in at less than half my Saturday average, and was a fair bit quicker than yesterday‚Äôs puzzle‚Äî which I also finished in less than average time‚Äî so I think the decision to change this from a Friday was perhaps mistaken. But YMMV! Funnily enough, it seemed intimidating at first, though, and I even wondered if I would be able to finish. The NW was definitely the hardest for me; the entirely unknown Lenny & LARRY‚ÄôS was my last fill-in. Guess they‚Äôre not gonna be replacing our favorite Oreos anytime soon! I did love SASHAY, though, and was rather proud that it came immediately to mind even though I‚Äôve never watched Ru Paul‚Äôs Drag Race!

Whew!  That was quite the workout.  I found myself constantly going down the wrong track on several clues.  Despite the jigs and jags,  the happy music finally played. Definitely Saturday level for me.
I was awful at mythology and not really into the classics, so this puzzle was a slog. Doesn‚Äôt make it bad, it just makes me kind of lowbrow.
Crossword RULE OF THUMB:  when the bound-to-be-right ACL TEAR starts to seem not right ‚Ä¶ it isn‚Äôt right.

It's still Friday here. So, I have a Friday question (unrelated to the crossword). Did anyone else see messages on nearly all NYT articles saying "Request comments to be opened" or something like that? It's the first time I've seen such a message. There are either a comments section or not at all, but never a request to open comments. I'm wondering if NYT was having a glitch or if this is a new policy. Does anyone know?

As usual, I was pretty sure I'd met my Waterloo.  At 45 minutes I had barely a few answers and none that I was really confident about.

It's always surprising, but bit by bit it finally unveiled itself.  Like others, 26D seemed to me that it had to be "acltear" or "ToRnacl".

Finally seeing TURFTOE really unblocked a lot of stuff.

I need to watch that new Apple movie with Anya Taylor-Joy. 

I have been generally unable to comment on anything recently because I‚Äôm just shutting down. To begin to comment is to scream until I‚Äôm empty.

Book about pickles: "The Salt in Our Jars"

(The author has an MBA: Master of Brine Arts.)

I much prefer a puzzle to take 30 minutes than an hour and 30 minutes, so enjoyed this. SW more tricky than NW, as I had NSA instead of NSC and couldn‚Äôt think of any combination of words that featured the string eaoi.
As an English professor who has taught ‚ÄúBeowulf‚Äù many, many times, I can assure you that 43D is incorrect. ‚ÄúThe supernatural descendant of Cain‚Äù is Grendel not Orc!!

Tough puzzle. For a while my one and only entry was POT BROWNIES.  When BACON STRIPS and STREET FAIR dropped in I realized that I was hungry.  

Watched another episode of "Smiley's People" tonight, which we do from time to time when we need some trusted escape. Now I'm tired and and will indulge in my favorite bedtime snack, plain Green Mountain Greek Yogurt with a drizzle of maple syrup, then off to dreamland.   Skipping the news.  I don't want to risk disturbing the neighbors with any excessively loud reactions. (Anyway, I've had enough for one day.)

Thank you for the puzzle, Ryan. It was a welcome distraction.  The high point was somehow remembering Atahualpa and even how to spell his name.

ATAHUALPA was a gimme, but one of the few among today's proper nouns. I needed a few lookups (MLB MVP, California brand, author, Parasite actor, Nintendo protagonist, river, and one or two other things) to get some crosses, but actually I had to rely on Google much less than yesterday, so I suppose for me Saturday's grid was easier than Friday's.

You know a puzzle is hard when you start wishing you‚Äôd read Beowulf. 

There was so much I didn‚Äôt know. TURF TOE, heh. Does it sprout (artificial) grass? Most of the names, and even a few things I was sure I had right. (Like ‚Äúnet‚Äù for ‚Äúcourt division‚Äù.) I have never heard PAR used as a verb, much less a past-tense one, so that threw me. 

I wish the Latte Larry‚Äôs clue had remained, because I would have gotten that one! (The cookies were no help.) And no fair teasing me with the thought of POT BROWNIES, which I do not have but sound really good right now.

In the clue for HEIR, I loved the clever ‚Äúif you will‚Äù after ‚ÄúNext in line.‚Äù

Fun puzzle!

This my kind of Saturday puzzle. Looked like I had only 4 or 5 answers filled on the first pass. Kept at it and just plugged away until I finished ‚Äî with no lookups! ‚Äî under my average time. Like others here, the NW corner was last to fall.

I loved some of the mind-stretching clues like [Means of children's instruction] and some of punny ones [Not from Scotland]. (Finally! A clue for NAE that (I hope) won‚Äôt raise the hackles of Scots solvers.)

But I made the mistake of starting this after dinner on a night following a full day of skiing in Utah. I got halfway through the grid before getting too drowsy to finish, so I set down my iPad and went to sleep. 

For some reason, when I go on a ski trip, I‚Äôm so exhausted that I‚Äôm asleep by 8 or 9, but I wake up anytime between 11:30 and 2 and can‚Äôt get back to sleep. When I woke before midnight and realized that I wasn‚Äôt getting back to sleep soon, I decided to finish the puzzle. 

The first thing I noticed was that for 34D [Big sucker], I had APHID POOL. I see how my sleepy brain came up with APHID (which, incidentally, I had misspelled), but what did that have to do with POOL? And yes, aphids suck (in more ways than one), but they are hardly ‚Äúbig.‚Äù

I finished the puzzle, in part thanks to gimmes I‚Äôd earlier missed like ANYA Taylor-Joy. (‚ÄúThe Queen‚Äôs Gambit‚Äù is worth watching, even if, like me, you don‚Äôt have any real interest in chess.)

And then I got the ‚Äúhorsefeathers‚Äù message. I looked through the grid and couldn‚Äôt see what was wrong. (In hindsight, my mistake must‚Äôve been 24A [Court division] nET ‚Äî a perfectly cromulent answer but for the obviously typo it left in 6D [Deems perfect, perhaps] RATEn A TEN.)

[to be continued]

Strands Thread:


Strands #363
‚ÄúLet us prey‚Äù
üü°üîµüîµüîµ
üîµüîµ

Testify to no spoilers until after the View All Replies button.


Amen.
My top crossword peeve, an unyielding NW corner.

A good one. There was trivia but the crossers happened to be very helpful to me this time, along with word knowledge - it can only be ANYA or Anna. Except for OHTANI, (not to mention MLBMVP), and TURF TOE, which I couldn't have guessed.  

As A Scot I would say NAW or NA for NO but maybe that's an Edinburgh/Leith thing.

As a Shohei Ohtani fan, I‚Äôm pleased to see him in an entry here (I have no access to XWord Info so I can‚Äôt confirm, but I suspect it‚Äôs a debut). Needless to say, I got it immediately, but I realize that it might be extreme trivia for those who aren‚Äôt baseball fans. I also realize that there would probably be many Yankees fans among the readers of a New York publication, and it might have triggered some traumatic memories.
California cookies crossed with Incan royalty ‚Ä¶ maybe I shouldn‚Äôt try to solve at 4 am.

Car makes, video games, snack brands, film actors, TV personalities, TV catchphrases, sport figures, text messages, fashion brands, fast food, and the obligatory drug reference. And we wonder where American education has gone. 

Even Beowulf couldn't save the day.
That was fun! Challenging but fair. Not too many extreme trivia and proper names were under control. Enjoyed answers falling into places at a steady pace

UNESCO, NSC, EPA, IRS?  Where's my chainsaw?  

Ryan Judge has been sent an email to report to the re-education camp.
I wouldn‚Äôt say unesco is a ‚Äòpeace‚Äô organisation. Their focus is culture. None of the UK unesco sites are known for needing peace keepers, except maybe on a Friday or Saturday night‚Ä¶

Needed lots of help for this one, but don‚Äôt mind on a Saturday .  
In-tents dining experience brought memories of how we had to eat if it started to rain while we were camping.

My first thoughts at 1 A was, "Is turmericy a word?, then "Rats, it doesn't fit anyway. " 

This wasn't particularly difficult, but my lack of knowledge of some of the names kept it from being a romp.  Still not a Saturday level for me, but it offered some resistance.  I especially liked the clues for SIMON SAYS and RARE COIN.

End of streak. Just got stuck in multiple places on this one and couldn't work it out. 

That's all on me. After review it doesn't look as hard as it was for me. Oh well. 

...
Good heavens. Talk about specialized information. What, you couldn't find a spot for "VP of Enid Rotary Removed after Bakery Incident"? :)

Lord but that was a brilliantly chewy offering. Well over my average time but worth it. I mean, Beowulf and Arachne, plus impossible to spell/pronounce Incan ruler, mixed in with POT BROWNIES and BACON STRIPS? Fabulous. 

I won‚Äôt nit pick the ORC as it‚Äôs been done so much better than I could further down. Ditto UNESCO as a peace keeping org. I tell you, them Druids at Stonehenge are a fighty lot, especially at summer Solstice.

1A threw me. As a carnivore I add salt to everything, including my coffee, to keep my potassium and magnesium levels up. My Doctor was horrified, until he saw that my blood pressure levels were lower than they‚Äôve been for years. 

I‚Äôll forgive the unknown cookie brand, sports name and gaming character as the rest was a brain teasing joy.

Off to poo pick my Alpaca field now, my lovely girls arrived Thursday. Man do they produce.
Never knew PAR could be a verb. I solved it thanks to the crosses, but was left wondering if it had something to do with stuffed grape leaves in Spanish-speaking countries (PARRA).

My two meta moments ‚Äì Entering TYPE IN, and silently laughing out loud at [Text that‚Äôs usually not literally true].






Et tu, emu.

I solved this, albeit with one incorrect square. Not a terribly difficult puzzle, yet a lot of great clues, but the fill was rife with trivia. Luckily, I figured out all the trivia because usually it stops me dead. I guess I am always going to be disappointed by most themeless puzzles because I enjoy all the clever themed ones so much more.
Did anyone else have 36A ending in -IPS and immediately enter POTATOCHIPS?
Overall decent for Saturday, but too many obscure or niche entries.
I struggled with POTBROWNIES because, without my conscious being aware of it, "pot" has become dated.

So punchy!

Had to give this one a little smack
for being so fresh!

Ryan Judge never fails to deliver the goods.

POY candidate, right here!

Wowza.

Oh, please give me things in the grid I don‚Äôt know, because I hunger for obstacles to overcome.  If crossed fairly ‚Äì and in the Times puzzle, they usually are ‚Äì these obstacles become riddles to figure out, manna for my brain.

Thus, I loved this puzzle with its passel of no-knows for me, bringing those ‚Äúdidn‚Äôt-know-it-yet-somehow-I-got-it‚Äù moments that even after all my years of crosswording, still amaze me.

The outing was enhanced by words I adore: HURTLE, RULE OF THUMB, FOB, GALOSHES, SASHAY, PUNCHY, BANSHEE, and SO TRUE.

The latter is exactly what I thought about the clue for LOL: [Text that‚Äôs usually not literally true].  I not only thought SO TRUE, but I not-literally punched the air with my fist to emphasize it!

And a shout-out bow-down to [Circles on the ice] for PUCKS, a clue that misdirected me seemingly forever, as I rooted my brain for figure skating terms.

Thus, a STREET FAIR for my brain, a delectable tour de box. Thank you so much for coming up with this, Ryan!

Strong and lively, like a Saturday puzzle.
With Atahualpa and Larry guiding my typin‚Äô thumbs, I could confidently punch A.

Not knowing the emperor or the cookie brand, and having FIRE and then FEED and finally FUEL for "Provide power to" made the NW quite difficult. 

A bit too much "trivia" in this one for my taste, but it must have been fair since I knew very little of it and still solved the puzzle unaided in about thirty minutes.

BANSHEE and WHIRLPOOL were nice verticals. Not so much for RARECOIN or SPINAWEB.

The NET/SET choice for "Court division" seems to catch me making the wrong choice first every time.

Solid Saturday.

As y'all know, the puzzle will often suggest pieces of music to me: here's two pieces for piano, unexpectedly similar, and which might not be to everyone's tastes, I admit: "The BANSHEE," from 1925, by Henry Cowell, in a rather elegantly videoed performance by Mirela Zhulali: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=VxjWep-JHYY And "Minerva's Web" by Stephen Scott and the Colorado-based BPE: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=VxjWep-JHYY (I admit, the video is 26 minutes long, with only the album cover for visuals, but I'm very, very fond of the piece. I had the pleasure of hearing the BPE and interviewing Mr. Scott when they performed at the Cleveland Museum of Art, many years ago--here's a 20 sec. clip which shows what's going on: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=VxjWep-JHYY) (Minerva was Arachne's competitor in the Great Greek Weave-Off.) Nice to see ELFs and ORCs not clued to Tolkien, even if not technically accurate; and even if Sam Lyons beat me to the Old English cut-7-paste. I often do it aloud--even if a muffled snortle--but seldom roll on the floor.

I was hoping 35D would have been REDCENTS, especially after I got "RULEOFTHUMB". Admittedly a bit of a stretch for the clue, but it is Saturday. I was also wondering who the obscure anthropologist expert Mr/Ms Wailer could be...
Salute to my 5th grade Social Studies teacher for ATAHUALPA. I'm in my 40s and I still remember that!

Started last night:  nope!

Tried again first thing this morning:  still bupkus!

Coffee, all the other puzzles, got a billable hour in, more coffee:  success!

It's all about focus.  

I givE, rank, RATE this one A TEN!

A tough one today‚Ä¶like many today it was the NW that stumped me for the longest time, though I did get hung up for awhile in the NE since I was confident that 9A was the MCAT and I kept trying to solve the crossing fills based on that. Ended up at five minutes over my average time, which would have been okay, except that because I have my usual Saturday food pantry shift this morning I broke down and looked up the name of the Incan emperor so I could finish. Some delightful clues throughout, however: 

‚ÄúSnack items that can go to your head,‚Äùfor POT BROWNIES, which took me back to college
‚ÄúIn-tents dining experience?‚Äù for STREET FAIR
‚ÄúSplashy footwear?‚Äù for GALOSHES

As a RULE OF THUMB I am wary of Saturday puzzles. After some BACON STRIPS for breakfast I SET out for the solve. But I soon realized I may as well of had POT BROWNIES because my brain felt LIMP. After a while of trial and error I put on my PARKA and GALOSHES, grabbed my car key FOB and drove down to the STREET FAIR where my chief AIM was to relax and get some brain FUEL. Solving can be tough as a SOLO ACT but I persevered. There was certainly some PUNCHY cluing and I continued to TYPE IN my answers on my IOS device. Finally after much struggle (and research) I solved it. YES! I feel like a BADASS.
Not a fan of this one. I look forward to doing the puzzle every morning with my coffee, before work. This one was no fun at all.
Good puzzle, but I don't believe Grendel was considered either an orc or an elf! At least not in my Anglo Saxon course!
Street fare before STREETFAIR

Thank you, Caitlin, for one of the long tricky clues!  I should have known it, as my generation practically invented the darn things.  I had huge swaths of white space up to that point.  Aside from the usual arcana, the clueing of everyday words and phrases was very clever.

Black hole before WHIRLPOOL.  Expose before EMBOSS.  Gives a ten before RATES A TEN.  Axels before PUCKS.  

?????? before ATAHUALPA.

LARRYS was last to fall, which made me feel like a big sucker.

I was just Doctor Smartypants this whole week, if my times are any indication. I join those throwing the flag on elf and orc, don‚Äôt really see what those have to do with Beowulf but ready to be educated if anyone feels differently.
I beg your PARRED'n?
Very good Saturday. Solved with no look ups in jussst under my average time. I had MONTEZUMA instead of ATAHUALPA for the longest time which caused a bit of bottleneck‚Ä¶

Steve often says that solving the puzzle for him is not a matter of if, but when. I'd like to get to that point.

I'd like to be more confident and optimistic.

Then again, maybe things really are every bit as bad as they seem.

Tough puzzle!

Things were going fairly well until the NW did me in.  My hat goes off to those who knew ATAHUALPA.  (I was trying to make Montezuma work, even though I know he's Aztec, not Inca).
Lenny & LARRY'S is no doubt a regional brand, but not my region.
And I need to spend more time with RuPaul, apparently. Had "gives" A TEN, rather than RATES; and was confused by the questionable ELF.

Trying to make progress in that corner with only ANYA and THETA as certain.
Oof!

I'm a little surprised I was able to finish this.  I knew almost nothing in it!  Sports are a black hole, I don't know Incan emperors or California cookies, and I didn't know the video game character either.

Very tough for me and every part of the grid presented difficult cluing.  In the end I think I enjoyed it.  :)

My kingdom for a theme.

____________________
Jesse Goldberg 8/28/2024 for Puzzle of the Decade
(emu filler)

Holy cow.
This was fairly brutal, given the number of "Unknowns to MOL"--which should be a Olympic category or something.  I am amazed and proud I solved  it.   Whew!

I put in, then took out, various guesses that turned out to be correct  or nearly so:  ATTUNE, SOURS, WHIRLsomething like WIND?
Despite having lived nearly 5 years in NoCal, did not know the cookies or the river.
UNESCO lists World Heritage sites, but World Peace?  After yesterday?

Our acquaintance with Big Rivers (the Ohio, the Arkansas, the Mississippi) educated us in re WHIRLPOOLs.  We learned that the eddies that exist near banks of these rivers can allow even a large riverboat or barge to remain in place without anchoring, and they are referred to as SUCKS.  (Hence "Toadsuck" near Conway, where we lived for 18 years.  Other, more colorful explanations for the name, are in error.)

Lots of puzzles created by men feature lots of sports clues - MVPs, coaches, and such - and video game clues - I get tired of areas of pop culture where I don't stand a chance - sigh - need more women to write puzzles!

PARKA seems a bit generic to be clued as "hunter's garb." You might as well answer BOOTS. Not really quibbling, just wanted an excuse to say "muk luks." And now I have.

Anyway, the word comes from Nenets (Siberian) and means "skin coat." The one I had as a kid was nylon, and was orange inside, for when I was stranded in the frozen wilderness of Massachusetts. Sealskin would have been better for waiting at the bus stop.
Anyone else getting a little tired of cast members from the film Parasite as clues? It‚Äôs time to move on, folks.
I guess it‚Äôs all about how you match up to the puzzle‚Äôs content. This one felt very easy to me vs a usual Saturday.

I don't know how a bunch of random intersecting proper nouns translates to being a challenge. NW was barely approachable. I had to run the alphabet on a box to clear this.
 
P.S. Bacon strips are not high in calories. Pork bacon is certainly high in fat, but your average strip has 30-35 calories.

I thought it was the crosser of ATAHUALPA and 3D that did me in, but it was HUSTLE instead of HURTLE. HUSTLE didn‚Äôt seem right as it didn‚Äôt fit ‚Äúuncontrollably‚Äù, but I couldn‚Äôt see the LARRYS in LARSYS. I thought the NW overall was a bit obscure even for a Saturday but I‚Äôll just take the L and move on.

Other than the nigh-impossible NW, this wasn't too challenging (9 min faster than my Sat average). I did go with POTmunchIES at first, though. And I only got CHINUPS through crosses: I was looking for something that actually connected those muscles. The NE corner was probably the easiest part of the grid.

Note to self: Learn to keep the Incas, Aztecs, and Mayas straight. Yes, Montezuma and ATAHUALPA have the same number of letters. So do LARRY'S and Benny's and Omega and THETA.

Also, I pronounce LSAT L-S-A-T. Ever since I took it in 1975 or so.

A question not related to this puzzle. When I opened the Wordplay column on Safari on the iPhone, there was a blue bot in the bubble that shows the number of comments.  Can someone please tell me what that signifies?

Thanks

Struggled with NW, as others, which broke open with just one lookup (Incan emperor), so not bad for a Saturday. But I‚Äôve never once eaten in a tent at a street fair. You eat en plein air, of course! (Which I also tried to make fit‚Äîcontrary to sense)

Great puzzle!  The NW corner was seemingly impossible at first glance, but got a toe-hold in the NE  corner with LSAT & LOL and proceeded generally clockwise from there. I'd never heard SASHAYAWAY before, but it's definitely my new favorite activity!

Boy, this started out as a very daunting puzzle, and with all the names and terms, I was getting a bit peeved.

But holy smokes, I chipped away until it all fell into place, the NW being the last to succumb to my brilliance (lol).

This took a little under 40 minutes for me. Until a day or two ago, I thought I was a mid-tier solver. Now I think I am closer to the lower rungs than I suspected.

BTW, if I were a constructor, I would want as much data and information as possible inre how my puzzles worked.

7 down and 43 down confused me.  I suppose you could infer that a monstrous being in ‚ÄúBeowulf‚Äù could be an elf or an orc, but as far as I know there are no elves or orcs explicitly mentioned ‚Äúin Beowulf‚Äù. Grendel is a ‚Äúmonster‚Äù and the other supernatural being is a dragon. Can anyone clear this up?

Everything went fast except for that NW corner that had me dead in the water. It is fun to go through the clues in order with a growing sense of despair only to find a toe hold somewhere from which to build out. And indeed that is how it went, with the SE being the first completed section for me, but after filling in everything but the NW I was still stymied by 13A, 1D, and 3D. Rough corner!

A tough puzzle even with Autocheck on. To a large extent I found the same parts difficult as those who do it the real way, e.g. the NW corner. But I knocked it off in 1:04:12 official time. (I must have remembered to turn the timer off before I quit for the night.)

Finished within seconds of my Saturday average - which is a lot slower than recent Saturdays. There seemed to be a lot of specialized knowledge required (more than seemed appropriate), but at least the crosses (while I wouldn‚Äôt say ‚Äúforgiving‚Äù) were mostly reasonable.  I needed literally every cross for 13a, and the NW was made particularly difficult for me by some incorrect initial guesses in that region (givESATEN, and HUsTLE, and seeing the AY at the end of 1d and knowing about RuPaul but not ever having seen Drag Race, my first thought was that it might end in SLAY). At least for a man of my age, FARRAH Fawcett was a gimme ü§ì

SAMUS was one of the few along with SASHAY I knew 100% on the first pass through. Pretty famous character even outside the Metroid games due to her inclusion in all the Nintendo smash bros games. Not really arcane at all.

My husband pointed out that, long before Tolkein, William Blake named one of the characters in his "America a Prophecy" ORC https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Orc_(Blake) So if ORC was necessary, there were a couple to choose from that didn't need the Beowulf gaff.

This one wasn‚Äôt an enjoyable solve for me. The only fact answer I 
knew was The Queen‚Äôs Gambit star, and a number of the clues were just off. Kia cancelled the Rio a couple years ago, so the clue should have reflected that. And maybe because I‚Äôm from the west coast but street fairs have in tent cooking, not dining. You get your food and eat it while enjoying warm sunny days.

The rest of the family solving committee was either in bed or glued to a video game and I had to tackle this alone. Both helpers were sorely missed. But, after clawing through 13A needing every single cross, I got the happy music and a smile on my face.

HURTLE is a word I don't see often enough.
Now for a PSA.
Happy March. That means it's time for a new bonus puzzle.  One needs to open gameplay in a browser to locate it.

Years ago, when I helped my mother do the crossword in our daily paper, there was always a hint if the answer was more than one word. (2 wds.) It seems today that most of the crosswords are made up of phrases and not just words.

My streak was at 931 when I completed the Friday 2/28 puzzle. I was not given credit for that completed puzzle. My streak should be 932. There must have been a glitch in the system. I want my streak back. I was hoping to get to 1000.
Just under 8 minutes to solve, after setting a new PB 6:15 for Friday yesterday.  Why are the puzzles so easy lately?

A couple of very unusual late puzzle finds. Don't recall seeing any others quite like these. First- A Sunday from July 13, 2003 by Randolph Ross with the title: "Words apart." One theme example which consisted of matching up 3 different answers (in away). First the 'reveal" "Description of 25- and 26-Across" BROKENPROMISE And then 25 and 26 across: "Senior event" PROM "Ending with real in London" ISE And, I'll leave out the clues (the first was always "Broken Promise" which mentioned to other answers. CLEFTPALATE PAL ATE PARTEDCOMPANY COMP ANY And some other 'reveal' answer. You can probably guess the referenced pair, but I'll mention them in parentheses. CHOPPEDSALADS (SAL ADS) SEPARATED COUPLES (COUP LES) And there were several more. Here's the Xword Info link if you want to go peruse that one: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=7/13/2003&g=67&d=A I'll put the other puzzle in a reply. ...

I just upgraded my NYT subscription to Full Access, which includes Games. Now, I‚Äôm told that I can cancel my prior separate Games subscription. I‚Äôm ready to do that, but I would like some assurance that cancellation of Games won‚Äôt wipe out my current hard earned Crossword streak. Does anyone know if it is safe to cancel Games and continue the streak on Full Access?
my river made the NYT Xword!

I was feeling a bit punky when I was done; I had nits with a few clues, it seemed trivia heavy--certainly full of things outside of my wheelhouse. But reading all the comments has actually brought me 'round: no, I absolutely didn't know ATAHUALPA, OHTANI, SAMUS, IRWIN, CHOI, Lenny and LARRY'S, or TURFTOE. But I was able to solve without lookups, which means the crosses must have been fair. And my time was only 2 minutes longer than my average. Nice to be able to change my mind about the puzzle. One nit I haven't seen mentioned yet: for 47A [Muscle that sounds encouraging, informally] I think the word order is sloppy. The muscle is the TRIceps; it's the informal version which sounds encouraging, so the clue should have been [Muscle that, informally, sounds encouraging]. FWIW the times did publish a correction for yesterday's Mufasa embarrassment: https://www.nytimes.com/2025/02/28/pageoneplus/corrections-march-1-2025.html
Loved this one! Plenty of PUNCHY clues and virtually no crossword-ese. Loved the WHIRLPOOL-shaped grid, too.

Got through it somehow. I agree about ORC though it‚Äôs been a long time since Beowulf.
